sentences.text: This paper solves a specialized regression problem to obtain sampling probabilities for records in databases .
The goal is to sample a small set of records over which evaluating aggregate queries can be done both efficiently and accurately .
We provide a principled and provable solution for this problem ; it is parameterless and requires no data insights .
Unlike standard regression problems , the loss is inversely proportional to the regressed-to values .
Moreover , a cost zero solution always exists and can only be excluded by hard budget constraints .
A unique form of reg-ularization is also needed .
We provide an efficient and simple regularized Empirical Risk Minimization -LRB- ERM -RRB- algorithm along with a theoretical generalization result .
Our extensive experimental results significantly improve over both uniform sampling and standard stratified sampling which are de-facto the industry standards .

kg2text: This paper presents an efficient and simple regularized Empirical Risk Minimization (ERM) algorithm that solves a specialized regression problem. The specialized regression problem, which is a specific type of problem, aims to obtain sampling probabilities for database records. The efficient and simple regularized Empirical Risk Minimization not only provides a theoretical generalization result but is also characterized as a principled and provable solution that is parameterless and requires no data insights. This principled and provable solution ensures the existence of a cost zero solution under certain constraints, thereby addressing the broader problem of sampling probabilities. The ultimate goal of this approach is to sample a small set of records, facilitating efficient and accurate evaluation of aggregate queries.

Standard regression problems are characterized by the presence of the loss, which is inversely proportional to the regressed-to values. To facilitate the evaluation of aggregate queries, a small set of records is utilized, which allows for efficient and accurate assessments. This small set has a broader term, encompassing records, which are individual entries in databases. The sampling probabilities for records in databases play a crucial role in this process, as they determine the likelihood of selecting specific records for analysis. Evaluating aggregate queries can be done efficiently and accurately, ensuring that the results are both precise and resource-effective. In the realm of statistical analysis, uniform sampling and standard stratified sampling are recognized as the industry standards. Our extensive experimental results demonstrate significant improvements over these traditional methods, showcasing the effectiveness of our proposed sampling techniques.

Records in databases are a specific type of data entry that falls under the broader category of databases, which are structured collections of data. In the context of financial limitations, a cost zero solution exists specifically under hard budget constraints, indicating that such a solution can only be disregarded when these strict financial limitations are in place. Furthermore, our extensive experimental results, which demonstrate the effectiveness of a proposed sampling method, are categorized under the broader term of experimental results. Similarly, extensive experimental results also fall under the umbrella of experimental results, highlighting the comprehensive nature of the findings obtained from systematic testing.
